pageData.text: Physical properties of soil affect many soil functions, including the movement of air, water, and heat through soil. In this investigation, students will measure three key physical properties that are critical to plant growth and other ecosystem services: soil , , and porosity.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 30 minutes 
Activity 1: Soil Bulk Density – 15 minutes 
Activity 2: Particle Density, Bulk Density, and Porosity of Sand – 40 minutes; 24–48 hours settling time

Water

text: Define <button class='glossary-text'>bulk density</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>particle density</button>, and porosity using words and equations.
Explain the importance of soil bulk density and porosity, especially for plant growth.
Measure bulk density of soil and particle density of sand.
Calculate porosity of soil from bulk density and particle density.
Analyze the relationships between bulk density, porosity, and soil texture by examining their equations and interpreting data.

pageData.text: Increased soil <button class='glossary-text'>bulk density</button> makes it harder for plants to grow in a soil as there is less space for roots to find their way through the soil and fewer pore spaces for water. This is a big concern in agriculture where crop yields are often dependent on the properties of the soil. Over multiple growing seasons, and with modern harvesting methods, the soil tends to compact, which can lead to decreased fertility. This, in turn, can cause farmers to apply more and more intensive interventions to get the same yields, which over time can lead to soil loss and environmental contamination. One strategy to combat this soil <button class='glossary-text'>compaction</button> and decreased porosity that is becoming increasingly common is the use of cover crops, or crops that are grown while a field is left fallow or in the off-season between harvest and planting. These cover crops, often grasses, are typically not grown to sell, but can be used as added organic material and fertilizer for the crop the following season. Using these crops has been shown to reduce soil density, increase porosity, and increase water infiltration of the soil by over 600%<sup>1</sup>. These cover crops also have the added benefits of increasing nitrogen fixation in the soil and even sequestering carbon from the atmosphere in some cases, which may help combat climate change.

1Haruna, S. I., Anderson, S. H., Udawatta, R. P., Gantzer, C. J., Phillips, N. C., Cui, S., & Gao, Y. (2020). Improving soil physical properties through the use of cover crops: A review. Agrosystems, Geosciences & Environment, 3 (1).
https://doi.org/10.1002/agg2.20105

pageData.altText: A field planted with a cover crop between growing seasons to protect the soil

pageData.subTitle: Soil Structure
pageData.text: Soil particles are arranged in soil to create soil structure (see Figure 1). Particles of various sizes, their relationship to one another, and the spaces between them all play a role in this structure. One key component of soil is the spaces between the particles, called pores, where air, water, and organisms can be found. This spatial arrangement affects the movement of air and water in soil, which in turn affects the growth of plants and microorganisms. Additionally, soil particles can stick together in clumps called in a process called . Because aggregation pulls particles together, large pores between individual particles, greater than 80 micrometers (μm) in size called , can be found between aggregates. Within aggregates, smaller pores less than 80 μm, or , can be found.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Soil, labeling the O-horizon (humus); A-horizon (topsoil); B-horizon (subsoil); C-horizon (weathered rock fragments); and D-horizon (bedrock)

pageData.text: These pores are very important to soil functioning because air and water flow quickly through macropores but slowly through micropores. Therefore, a soil with a greater degree of aggregation can better provide air and water to plant roots, supporting plant growth (see Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Two illustrations: a plant growing in soil with good tilth and a plant in soil with all three types of compaction

pageData.subTitle: Soil Bulk Density
pageData.text: Soil structure is very closely interrelated with soil texture, , and porosity. Measuring soil bulk density is one way to quantitatively assess soil structure. Bulk density is the weight of the solid particles in a given volume of dry soil (which includes both solids plus pore space occupied by air). The bulk density of soil affects numerous soil properties, including aeration, drainage, water retention, and suitability for construction projects. The standard equation for measuring bulk density is:

pageData.altText: Equation 1: D sub b equals begin fraction M sub s over V sub s end fraction equals begin fraction mass of dry soil over volume of dry soil end fraction

pageData.text: In this equation, Db is the soil bulk density, Ms is the dry soil mass, and Vs is the dry soil volume (see for a conceptual illustration).

Given the nature of the equation, a soil with high bulk density will be dense, having smaller pore spaces overall. Generally, a soil with good and overall structure will have a bulk density of about 1.3 g/cm3 or lower. If soil bulk density becomes too high (above ~1.5 g/cm3), plant growth may be inhibited because plants have trouble pushing their roots through dense soils and porosity of dense soils is too low to support sufficient air and water flow.

When measuring bulk density, it is important to collect the soil “intact” without breaking up or compressing the soil. Therefore, digging up soil and putting it into a container does not result in an accurate measurement— in the field, soil bulk density is affected by aggregation, but digging up soil breaks up these aggregates and changes the bulk density. Given this, to collect a sample for measuring bulk density, a core sample is taken (see Figure 3). The one exception to this rule is sand soils, which do not have significant aggregation because sand particles are not sticky.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A sample of soil in a cylinder can

pageData.text: An additional important physical characteristic of soils is . Particle density describes the weight of solid particles in a given volume (see Figure 4), or the average density of individual particles (not including pores). It is equivalent to specific gravity of a solid material and is calculated with the following equation:

pageData.altText: Equation 2: D sub p equals begin fraction M sub p over V sub p end fraction equals begin fraction mass of particles over volume of particles end fraction

pageData.text: In this equation, Dp is the particle density, Mp is the mass of the particles, and Vp is the volume of the particles. Mineral soils (soils containing <30% ) typically have a particle density of 2.65 g/cm3. Given this consistency in particle density, it is usually not necessary to calculate the particle density of soil. Exceptions are soils very rich in organic matter, which would be expected to have a lower-than-average particle density, or soils rich in minerals, which would be expected to have a higher-than-average particle density.

The most common method for measuring particle density is by using Archimedes’ principle of displacement. In this method, a known volume of water (Vw) is mixed with a known mass of dry soil (Mp). When all pores of the soil are filled with water, the total volume of the soil-water mixture is measured. The volume of water displaced by the soil is equal to the volume of the soil particles (Vp). With sand, this procedure is quite simple. Care must be made with soils with significant amounts of silt and clay, as in these sediments will retain air even after vigorous mixing.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Three boxes: Box A is solid brown. Box B is white with brown specs. Box C is equally divided with solid brown on the bottom and solid white on top.

pageData.question: What will happen to plant growth if the soil’s bulk density is greater than 1.5 g/cm<sup>3</sup>?

options.text: Growth will be inhibited because the porosity is too low to allow sufficient air flow and water.
Growth will be inhibited because there will not be enough nutrients.
Growth will be accelerated because the compact soil will be nutrient rich.
Growth will be accelerated because the low porosity means the soil can hold onto the water long enough for the plant to take root.
Growth rate of plants is not affected by the bulk density of the soil.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Generally, a soil with good aggregation and overall structure will have a bulk density of about 1.3 g/cm<sup>3</sup> or lower. If soil bulk density becomes too high (above ~1.5 g/cm<sup>3</sup> ), plant growth may be inhibited because plants have trouble pushing their roots through dense soils and porosity of dense soils is too low to support sufficient air and water flow.

pageData.question: Which of the following is commonly used to measure particle density in soil?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The most common method for measuring particle density is by using Archimedes’ principle of displacement. In this method, a known volume of water (V<sub>w</sub>) is mixed with a known mass of dry soil (M<sub>p</sub>). When all pores of the soil are filled with water, the total volume of the soil-water mixture is measured. The volume of water displaced by the soil is equal to the volume of the soil particles (V<sub>p</sub>). With sand, this procedure is quite simple. Care must be made with soils with significant amounts of silt and clay, as micropores in these sediments will retain air even after vigorous mixing.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Soil structure is very closely interrelated with soil texture, bulk density, and porosity. Measuring soil bulk density is one way to quantitatively assess soil structure. Bulk density is the weight of the solid particles in a given volume of dry soil (which includes both solids plus pore space occupied by air). The bulk density of soil affects numerous soil properties, including aeration, drainage, water retention, and suitability for construction projects.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Soil structure is very closely interrelated with soil texture, bulk density, and porosity. Measuring soil bulk density is one way to quantitatively assess soil structure. Bulk density is the weight of the solid particles in a given volume of dry soil (which includes both solids plus pore space occupied by air). The bulk density of soil affects numerous soil properties, including aeration, drainage, water retention, and suitability for construction projects.

pageData.subTitle: Soil Porosity
pageData.text: Another important characteristic of any soil is its porosity, which is the total volume of all pores in the soil. Since pore spaces contain air and water, in soils with greater porosity, plants will have greater access to oxygen and water. Soil porosity can be calculated with the following equation:

pageData.altText: Equation 3: porosity equals 1 minus begin fraction D sub b over D sub p end fraction

pageData.text: In this equation, Db is the of the soil in g/cm3 and Dp is the in g/cm3. The units of this fraction cancel, and thus porosity is a unitless fraction. Because of this, soil porosity is often expressed as a percent (%) and can be calculated by multiplying the fraction obtained using the formula by 100.

Porosity and bulk density are inversely correlated, so as bulk density increases, porosity decreases. Therefore, denser soils have a lower total pore volume. Soils with high bulk densities (>1.5 g/cm<sup>3</sup>) negatively affect plant growth in a large part due to their low porosity. Air and water flow slower through soil with less pore space and/or a smaller average pore size, making it harder for plant roots to get water and oxygen. Furthermore, soils with lower total porosity hold onto less water after rain, and as a result, there is less water in the soil for plants in between precipitation events.

pageData.subTitle: Natural Factors Affecting Soil Structure, Bulk Density, and Porosity
pageData.text: Numerous natural factors, primarily other soil properties, affect soil structure, which in turn affects bulk density and porosity, mainly soil texture and <button class='glossary-text'>organic matter</button> present.

The distribution of sand, silt, and clay particles in soil determines the texture of a soil and arguably has the largest impact of all soil properties on the structure of mineral soils. This distribution has an impact on both the size and number of pore spaces, and with more spaces, as mentioned earlier, more water and air are available in the soil. Between large sand particles are large pores because these are large particles. However, between small particles, such as clay, are small particles. The effect of the number of pores on porosity is far greater than the effect of the average pore size. As particle size decreases, the number of increases drastically, thereby increasing the overall porosity of the soil (see ).

Both soil texture and influence soil structure through . In general, well-aggregated soils have a greater porosity because, although themselves are dense, aggregation creates in between the aggregates. Due to the of clays, clayey soils have a greater degree of aggregation. Of sand, silt, and clay, only clays are sticky. Clays are sticky because clay particles have a negative charge, and particles are arranged in layers that have positively charged cations in between each layer. Therefore, clay particles, through the cations in between, are attracted to each other and tend to , or stick together. This stickiness of clays helps soil aggregates form and stay intact. Organic matter is similarly sticky and helps aggregate soil particles.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Bar graph showing clay with a larger amount of micropores, in orange, as compared to macropores, in blue. Loam soil has a close to equal amount of micro and macro pores; sandy loam has about three times as much macropores as micropores.

pageData.text: Organic matter also influences soil due to its low . Organic matter is composed mainly of the elements carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen. These elements are less dense than the elements that comprise the most abundant minerals, such as silicon and iron. As particle density decreases, bulk density also decreases. Therefore, soils rich in organic matter have low bulk densities. Organic matter on average has a particle density of about 1 g/cm3, and organic soils (soils containing >30% organic matter) can have bulk densities even lower. Organic matter particles themselves can be porous as well, much like sponges, further decreasing soil bulk density.

Depth in the soil profile also affects soil bulk density. Deeper in the soil profile, bulk densities tend to be higher due to the weight of the upper layers pressing down on the lower layers, compacting them. The weight of glaciers can similarly compact soil. As a result, some subsoils where glaciers once flowed have especially high bulk densities, sometimes 2.0 g/cm3 or more.

pageData.subTitle: Management Factors Affecting Soil Structure, Bulk Density, and Porosity
pageData.text: Various management practices can compact soil over time, increasing its . is the compression of soil by a downward force. Heavy machinery, such as tractors and trucks, can press down on soil and cause compaction over time. During the compaction process, particles press closer and closer together, reducing both the average pore size and total porosity. Soil is especially vulnerable to compaction when wet, so driving over wet soil should be avoided to prevent compaction. Using wider tires also reduces compaction by spreading out the weight of the vehicle over a larger area, reducing the pressure per square inch. Compaction in surface layers can cause agricultural soils to have a higher bulk density in the uppermost horizon (layer) compared with the horizon directly below it, unlike soils that have not been compacted by human activity.

, the intentional mixing of soil by humans, can increase plant growth in the short term but degrades soil structure in the long term. Tillage breaks up , destroying soil structure. The immediate effect of this is to “fluff up” the soil, reducing its density and making it easier for plants to grow. However, without as many aggregates, soil is less able to resist the weight of vehicles pressing down on it. Thus, tillage makes soil more vulnerable to compaction, and therefore tillage actually increases bulk density in the long term.

Furthermore, tillage exposes the normally protected by aggregates to oxygen. With oxygen readily available, microbes decompose the organic matter much faster, turning much of it into carbon dioxide. Tillage also mixes in plant material that normally rests on the surface of the soil, again making it easier for microbes to decompose. Thus, tillage also reduces soil organic matter in the long term, causing a further increase in bulk density and decrease in .

In this lab, you will measure the mass and volume of soil samples and use them to calculate bulk density (Db), (Dp), and porosity. The data will inform your understanding of soil , the overall physical quality of the soil and ability to physically support plant growth.

pageData.question: Wet soil can easily be compacted. Soil compaction should be avoided in order to maintain the porosity of the soil.  What is one way to prevent compaction?

options.text: Use wider tires to reduce the pressure per square inch.
Till the soil as soon as it gets wet.
Spread organic matter over the soil to change the composition.
Dig drainage ditches to channel excess water away from the soil.
Mix sand into the soil to increase porosity and reduce stickiness of soil.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Using wider tires also reduces compaction by spreading out the weight of the vehicle over a larger area, reducing the pressure per square inch.

pageData.question: What is an unintended side effect of tillage?

options.text: Oxygen escapes the soil faster and prevents decomposition.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Tillage exposes the organic matter normally protected by aggregates to oxygen. With oxygen readily available, microbes decompose the organic matter much faster, turning much of it into carbon dioxide.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Various management practices can compact soil over time, increasing its bulk density. Compaction is the compression of soil by a downward force. Heavy machinery, such as tractors and trucks, can press down on soil and cause compaction over time. During the compaction process, particles press closer and closer together, reducing both the average pore size and total porosity. Soil is especially vulnerable to compaction when wet, so driving over wet soil should be avoided to prevent compaction. Using wider tires also reduces compaction by spreading out the weight of the vehicle over a larger area, reducing the pressure per square inch. Compaction in surface layers can cause agricultural soils to have a higher bulk density in the uppermost horizon (layer) compared with the horizon directly below it, unlike soils that have not been compacted by human activity.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect a soil sample. In activity 1, you will measure the mass and volume of all of your soil samples. In activity 2, you will measure the mass and volume of the water and of the sand. Then, you will add the sand to the water and record the total volume and actual sand volume. Next, you will photograph your sample. Then, you will allow the sand to completely dry. You will do this for both types of sand.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for the laboratory activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

Never conduct fieldwork on your own, especially in remote areas; always take a responsible partner with you. Prepare and leave a field safety plan, complete with planned survey locations and expected return time, with a responsible party. Wear appropriate clothing (long pants and close-toed shoes are usually best), sunblock, and insect repellant if necessary. Be familiar with the potential hazards in your chosen survey areas. Please review the “Field Work” portion of the Laboratory Safety Manual or your school’s specific safety guidelines for more information. Make sure that you are healthy enough to participate in fieldwork. If in doubt, consult your medical practitioner.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Review the background information and activity instructions.
Obtain all items from Materials and PPE. Clean and sanitize the work area.

Using the 24-ounce deli container from the equipment kit, collect approximately ½ cup of soil from about 0–8 cm (0–3 inches) below the surface. This sample is the “Collected Soil” sample and will be used in both activities. Before using the sample, remove excess grasses, roots, and other plant materials and break up any large clumps.

If you are unsure if a public location is appropriate to collect a sample from, contact your local Parks and Recreation, Fish and Wildlife, State Park, Bureau of Land Management, or National Forest Department.
Note: If your soil has a substantial amount (>10% or so) of course fragments like gravel, you will need to sieve it with a colander or a sieve.

Spread the soil out on newspaper or parchment paper and allow it to dry for ~24h (more time may be needed in humid climates).You may find it easier to break up aggregates part way through drying, depending on the soil's initial moisture and its particle size distribution. Repeat this step for soil sample Z and the coarse (marine) sand.
In Activity 1, you will compare the <button class='glossary-text'>bulk density</button> of different soil types by measuring their masses and volumes.
Using the digital balance, weigh the 100 mL graduated cylinder. Record its mass in Data Table 1.
Fill the 100 mL graduated cylinder with approximately 30 mL of the “Collected Soil” sample.
The "Collected Soil" sample must be dry.
Gently tap the side of the cylinder to fill in large gaps between particles and the cylinder. Do not press down on the soil. Record the exact volume of the soil in Data Table 1.

Note: This method is designed for sand soils and is prone to error when using silty or clayey soil. This is largely caused by excessively large gaps between soil and the cylinder. Careful tapping helps reduce the amount of error by helping particles fill the gaps.
Weigh the 100 mL graduated cylinder with dry soil in it. Record the mass in Data Table 1.
Put the sample back in the container. You will need it for Activity 2.
Repeat Steps 1–5 for the fine sand, the marine (coarse) sand, and “Soil Sample Z.”

In Activity 2, you will compare the , , and porosity of two types of sand by first measuring their masses and volumes, then measuring the total volume and actual sand volume after adding water to the samples.

pages.title: Particle Density and Porosity of Sand (17 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Particle Density and Porosity of Sand (17 steps)

pageData.text: Use the 100 mL graduated cylinder to measure 50 mL of water.
Note: Remember to measure volume from the bottom of the meniscus (see Figure 6).

pageData.altText: Figure 6: The liquid in a cylinder where it forms a curve called the meniscus read at eye level

pageData.text: Using the digital balance, weigh the 100 mL graduated cylinder containing 50 mL of water. Record the mass in Data Table 1.
Remove the cylinder from the balance.
Weigh the 50 mL graduated cylinder, and record the mass in Data Table 1.
Pour 44–45 mL of course sand into the 50 mL graduated cylinder.
Weigh the 50 mL graduated cylinder containing the coarse sand, and record your results in Data Table 1.
Carefully pour the coarse sand from the 50 mL graduated cylinder into the water in the 100 mL graduated cylinder. Tap the graduated cylinder, and make sure there are no bubbles.
Record the final total volume of the water and sand (Vf) in Data Table 1.
Record the actual sand volume (Vs) in Data Table 1 (see Figure 7).

pageData.altText: Figure 7: A graduated cylinder containing sand and water. The following measurements are indicated - V sub s, or the volume of sand, including pore spaces; the initial water volume, before sand; and the final water volume. The volume of water between the initial water volume and final water volume measurements is labeled V sub p, or change in volume.

pageData.text: Note: This activity is based on Archimedes’ principle of displacement. The volume of the sand is equal to the amount of water it displaces. The water will rise by a volume equal to the volume of the sand particles only (not the pores).

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a picture of the sample.
Pour your sample (sand and water) from the graduated cylinder into a plastic cup.
Note: If you try to pour your sample directly from the graduated cylinder onto cardboard or a sheet of newspaper, the soil will get stuck at the bottom, and it will be difficult to remove.
Carefully pour off the water from your soil sample into a sink.
Pour the soil sample onto cardboard or a sheet of newspaper labeled with the soil name. If using newspaper, place it on a towel.
Allow your sample to completely dry, 24–48 hours.
Once the soil is dry, put it back into the bag. You may need to use the sample again in another investigation.
Repeat Steps 5–15 with the fine sand.

text: Which should have the higher bulk density - sand or clay? Which of these should have a greater total porosity?
Compare the bulk densities of the coarse sand, fine sand and soil sample Z. Do your results agree your hypothesis and answer to Question 1? Why or why not?
Compare and contrast the bulk density of your collected soil with the other samples. Is it higher or lower than the sand sample? How does it compare to Sample Z? What might cause these differences?
For the sand samples, were your particle density results close to (within 5% of) the conventional value of 2.65 g/cm<sup>3</sup>? If not, what may have caused the difference?

A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before beginning, you will collect a soil sample. In activity 1, you will measure the mass and volume of all of your soil samples. In activity 2, you will measure the mass and volume of the water and of the sand. Then, you will add the sand to the water and record the total volume and actual sand volume. Next, you will photograph your sample. Then, you will allow the sand to completely dry. You will do this for both types of sand.
Figure 6: The liquid in a cylinder where it forms a curve called the meniscus read at eye level

Figure 7: A graduated cylinder containing sand and water. The following measurements are indicated - V sub s, or the volume of sand, including pore spaces; the initial water volume, before sand; and the final water volume. The volume of water between the initial water volume and final water volume measurements is labeled V sub p, or change in volume.

data.title: Aggregate
data.content: A clump of soil that is stuck together

data.title: Aggregation
data.content: The process of clumping soil together

data.title: Bulk density
data.content: The weight of solid partices in a given volume of dry soil, which includes solids plus pore space occupied by air

data.title: Compaction
data.content: The compression of soil by a downward force

data.title: Macropore
data.content: A large pore (greater than 80 micrometers) between individual particles that can be found between aggregates

data.title: Micropore
data.content: A small pore (less than 80 micrometers) found within aggregates

data.title: Organic matter
data.content: Dead and decomposing organism tissues along with living microorganisms

data.title: Particle density
data.content: The weight of solid partices in a given volume, not including the pores

data.title: Stickiness
data.content: The degree to which soil particles are attracted to each other

data.title: Tillage
data.content: The intential mixing of soil by humans to increase plant growth in the short term, but which degrades the soil in the long term
